subject: Re: [junit] how to test java objects created from XML file
msgSnippet: Why would you need to extend the Assert class?  Just make an equals() method in the helper and your main class, and do an assertEquals(helper, testObject). Or

Why would you need to extend the Assert class?  Just
make an equals() method in the helper and your main
class, and do an assertEquals(helper, testObject).

Or am I misunderstanding what it is you are trying to
accomplish?

-Eric

--- pisharath_k <pisharath_k@...> wrote:
> I have a basic question. I have a set of classes
> whose values are set 
> from a file by a Reader object. Now I want to test
> whether these 
> values are set correctly. I can use preset values
> for testing 
> purpose. But due to the large number and complexity
> of these classes 
> it would be very difficult and cumbersome to create
> objects with 
> these preset values manually for testing against the
> ones created by 
> the Reader.
> 
> I am thinking of creating a helper class for each of
> the above 
> classes. I will pass it the object to compare, and
> it will compare 
> the object's data against pre-defined values that
> will be stored in 
> the helper classes. I will need to extend junit's
> Assert class for 
> these helper class, since they will assert if there
> is a data 
> mismatch. So my question is,  is it okay to extend
> Assert in my own 
> classes ? Has anyone faced this problem before, and
> if so how did you 
> solve this ? Any help will be appreciated.
> 
> Thanks,
> - krishnan
> 
>
